about.aboutContent:
Background

This Hamilton Area Candidate Investment Properties web application is a decision support system for PRJ Group, Inc. that provides information about prospective investment properties (aka housing flips) in the Hamilton area of Ontario. The primary purpose of the system is to help PRJ Group determine an offer price for a prospective property that has a reasonable chance of making a profit while also having a reasonable chance of being the highest offer and therefore being accepted. The “hot” resale housing market in the Hamilton area often results in a listed property receiving multiple competing offers thereby bidding up home selling prices to levels that make it difficult to make a profit from renovating and then reselling the property.

Web Application Overview

The web app contains a customized web map of the Hamilton area and four feature layers:

  1. Candidate Properties: point layer for information, e.g., address, MLS#, selling price, condition, about active candidate investment properties, and historical information investment properties that were analyzed but are no longer active.
  2. Comparable Properties: point layer that includes list and selling prices for properties in neighborhoods close to a candidate property, that are “comparable” in style, size, condition, etc.
  3. Neighborhoods and Communities: polygon layer of neighborhoods and communities in the Hamilton area colour-coded with a subjective rating of resale quality for properties.
  4. Building Supply Stores: polygon layer that is used to create distance buffers for the building supply features on the map.

The web app contains the following widgets:

  • Active Candidate Properties Only filter widget
Filter removes historical investment properties that are no longer active from the web map. Only active candidate properties still under consideration for purchase are shown on the map.
  • Comparable Properties for Investment Candidate filter widget
Filter prompts for the address of a candidate property, then displays comparable properties only for that candidate property. All other comparable properties are removed from the map.
  • Neighborhood Resale Quality filter widget
Filter prompts for Resale Quality, then displays colour-coding only for neighborhoods that have that have that quality rating.

  •           Pop-up widget
        Pop up window remains active and can be moved to different areas of the map.

  •           Buffer widget

     Widget allows distance buffers to be drawn around locations on the map for various feature layers. Used primarily to draw buffer around building supply stores to help with determination of renovation cost for a candidate investment property.

Credits

The web app was created by Jeff Machesky, owner of PRJ Group, Inc. using ArcGIS WebApp builder, ArcGIS Online, Mapbox, and Overpass Turbo. Information for the map was provided by PRJ Group, Inc., City of Hamilton, and Open Streetmaps (using Overpass turbo).

More details about the web map, hosted feature layers and investment process supported by the tool are provided below.

Web map and hosted feature layers

1.       Web map  – created in ArcGIS Online

a.       Basemap:

                                                               i.       Initial Mapbox Studio style and tileset:

The basemap is a Mapbox style with an added tileset that was created using point data from Open Streetmaps for Building Supply stores in the Hamilton area. The Streetmaps point data was gathered using a query from Overpass Turbo. The Overpass query data was exported as a GeoJSON file, saved, and then imported into Mapbox. In Mapbox a tileset was created using the imported GeoJSON file, and then incorporated into the style as a custom layer. The components and layers of the style were then customized with grey neutral colors, and the labels for building supply features were removed so the labels wouldn’t clash with the added building supply layer from Open Streetmaps. Other cosmetic changes were also made to the style, primarily in colors,  sizes and visibilities of labels so the basemap features would not clash with the feature layers that would be added later to the web map in Arcgis Online.

                                                             ii.      ArcGIS Online

An ArcGIS web map called Hamilton Area Property Analysis was created. The basemap for the web map was created by importing the Mapbox style as a tile layer using the integration URL provided by Mapbox as a tile layer. Hosted Feature Layers were then created and added to the ArcGIS web map.

2.       ArcGIS Hosted Feature Layers

a.       Candidate Properties

Hosted point feature layer that captures information about properties in the Hamilton area that are for sale and have been viewed with the help of a real estate agent. Information is initially captured on an iPhone by a PRJ Group estimator during the site visit using the ArcGIS field maps application, and updated after the visit.

Information captured during site visit includes:

-          Property location (using phone GPS)

-          Photos of property (only outside photos are included for this assignment due to privacy issues. Inside photos are also available to PRJ Group).

-          MLS number

-          Address

-          Size in sq ft

-          List price

-          Condition (Excellent, Good, Fair, Poor, Tear Down)

-          Comments (general comments about state of the house and renovations required)

-          Estimator


Information updated after visit:

-          Estimated renovation cost

-          Offer price (if offer is made)

-          Offer date (if offer made)

-          Sold price (for historical purposes)

-          Active flag (Y/N)

b.       Comparable properties

Hosted point feature layer that captures information about comparable properties in the neighborhood of the candidate investment property. Information is provided by the real estate agent and then entered by PRJ Group estimator using ArcGIS Online. Data fields:

-          MLS number

-          Address

-     Address of candidate investment property (establishes relationship with Candidate property feature layer)

-          List price

-          Sale price

c.       Neighborhoods and communities

Hosted polygon feature layer of Hamilton area neighborhoods and communities obtained from the City of Hamilton open data portal. Grimsby and Burlington communities were added manually based on areas in those cities that PRJ Group searches for properties in. Information about neighborhood resale quality was added to the feature layer by PRJ Group based on subjective experience viewing homes in those neighborhoods. Data fields:

-          Resale Quality (Excellent, Good, Neutral, Fair, Poor)

-          Resale Factor (10, 5, 0, -5, -10)

Resale Factor is sometimes used to adjust offer price on a property


-          Number (identification number created by City of Hamilton)


d.       Building supply stores

Hosted polygon feature layer created from building supply stores layer that was created from Open Streetsmap and Overpass Turbo. The building supply stores layer is used by the Buffer widget to create buffers for building supply stores on the basemap. The buffers are used to help determine renovation costs for candidate investment properties. I.e., closeness to a building supply store lowers renovation costs.

High-level investment process

The following is the high-level process used by PRJ Group, Inc. to determine if an offer will be made for a property, and for how much:

  •         Daily: review list of potential investment properties provided by real estate agent.
  •         Weekly: determine candidate investment properties to visit and arrange with agent to visit properties (normally 4-5 visits on the same day).
  •         Same day: visit the candidate properties and record information, including photos and comments, about each property during walkthough with real estate agent.
  •         As provided: review comparable properties for selected candidate properties provided by real estate agent.
  •         Ongoing: for the visited candidate properties, determine renovations required and renovation cost, expected selling price for the renovated property and neighborhood, and estimate highest offer price possible that will result in a profit for the property. Factors that will influence the renovation cost, and selling and offer prices include:

a.       condition of property and scope and difficulty of renovations, including closeness of building supply stores to the property.

b.       list and sale prices of comparable properties in the neighborhoods close to the prospective investment property; and

c.       quality of the neighborhood in terms of desirability to live there, overall prices of homes in the neighborhood, etc.

  • Every 1-2 weeks: make an offer for a property with help of the agent (usually one offer for every five or six properties visited).
